III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure
Section facilities; seclusion plan; prohibitions; reduction and
Description elimination
(11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Between 7/1/25-8/19/25, the facility was using seclusions as a
form of consequence/punishment rather than a life saving
measure, which is against the terms of their approved seclusion
variance.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via video
conference on 8/25/25. CA reviewed various seclusions with
Consultant between the dates of 7/1/25-8/19/25. CA reported it
appeared roughly half of the seclusion reports were written poorly
because they lacked detail regarding de-escalation efforts and key
details which occurred prior to the seclusion. CA reported the
other half of the seclusions are likely due to staff and supervisors
falling back into the “old way” of doing things. CA reported the
recent construction to their facility didn’t help because they didn’t
have any day room space to allow youth to “cool off” in a neutral
area. CA reported now that construction is finished, there are
more spaces and opportunities for separation of youth from the
group during escalated situations. CA reported supervisors review
seclusion reports and ultimately team leaders sign off on them,
therefore, the discussion about seclusions and when they’re
allowed needs to be held at all levels. CA reported they have
already been speaking to staff about running the behavior
management program as intended since they only have 10 youth
currently because when they increase capacity the number of
escalated situations or problems will likely increase as well.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• The facility has had variances approved every two months
regarding this rule since July 1, 2024. The variance
approval letter outlines seclusions can only be used under
certain circumstances with certain provisions in place. Of
note it states:
o Staff must only use seclusion as a temporary
response to prevent life-threatening injury or serious
bodily harm when other interventions are ineffective.
o Prior to seclusion, staff must use less restrictive
techniques to de-escalate the situation such as
2

talking with youth, bringing in other staff or qualified
mental health professionals to assist, or engaging
family members or other youth to talk with the youth.
• Seclusion Reports (15 of 38) were reviewed dated between
7/1/25-8/19/25 and none of them met the requirements of
the facility’s approved variance. There was a lack of
documented efforts to de-escalate the youth prior to issuing
seclusion, and it was apparent from the narratives,
seclusion was being used as a consequence/punishment
rather than a life-saving measure. There were also several
times the youth were separated from the group to calm
down, but then still put in seclusion even after the reports
documented the youth were calm.
• Behavior Management Rooms, Room Restriction and
Room Checks Policy states a security violation time out
(aka seclusion) shall be issued if a resident displays life-
threatening behaviors or to prevent serious bodily harm to
self or others when other interventions are ineffective.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per documentation reviewed
and the interview conducted the facility is not meeting the
requirements of their approved variance regarding seclusions.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Consultant discussed the fifteen seclusion narratives reviewed
and provided the CA with a summary of the concerns
demonstrating how the seclusions did not meet the requirements
of their approved variance.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection dated 11/6/24; CAP approved 11/22/24
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
